properties.Project Name: Biofiltration Swale and NGPA Restoration Project
properties.Short Project Summary: Supports the restoration of two bio-filtration swales and over 200 feet of Native Growth Protection Area (NGPA) bordering a wetland by converting mowed lawn to native plants. The native plants will slow and filter contaminated stormwater runoff from a large church parking lot that empties through two bio-filtration swales directly into a wetland. The wetland flows into Upper Chennault Ravine and runs down to enter Puget Sound at Chennault Beach. Slowing the flow of water entering the wetlands from the bio-filtration swales and NGPA will improve the capacity of the wetland to remove contaminants, will increase ground water recharge, and will provide wildlife habitat.

properties.Project Name: Nisqually Reach Aquatic Reserve Project
properties.Short Project Summary: Funds citizen science research in the Nisqually Reach Aquatic Reserve and supports the management of volunteers supporting the Aquatic Reserve and coordinating citizen science research. The Aquatic Reserve is one of five reserves located throughout Puget Sound on state-owned aquatic lands. As part of the management plan, citizen stewardship committees have been formed to allow citizens to participate in scientific investigation, outreach activities, and the permit review process, increasing the knowledge base for the Aquatic Reserve and also fostering a connection between local residents and the impact of shoreline development and water quality. This grant also supports the expansion of direct water quality monitoring through the Department of Fish and Wildlife�s (WDFW) Mussel Watch program. Citizens will be trained to participate in the permit review process, giving committee members the baseline knowledge about permit reviews necessary to understand their role. This professional training will allow citizens to comment on proposed projects throughout the Nisqually Reach Aquatic Reserve and empower them to make their voices heard.

properties.Project Name: Kilbourne Ravine Riparian and Buffer Project
properties.Short Project Summary: Part of a 6 year project to restore native riparian and buffer habitat in the ravine that drains into the middle reach of Fauntleroy Creek, a coho-bearing urban stream in central Puget Sound. The restored habitat will maximize prevention of erosion from steep slopes, filtration of runoff, retention of precipitation in conifer canopy, and shade to discourage invasive return. The project will also enlist ravine property owners and neighbors in recognizing and removing invasive species from their own landscaping. The overall project involves private property, undeveloped City of Seattle right-of-way and Kilbourne Park, a natural area in the Seattle Parks and Recreation system, for a fully collaborative approach to full restoration of Kilbourne Ravine.

properties.Project Name: Friends of North Creek Forest Phase 2
properties.Short Project Summary: Supports the expansion of volunteer capacity to control erosion affecting water quality in North Creek, a Sammamish River tributary containing Chinook salmon and other salmon species. Activities include repair of eroded areas and elimination of invasive plant species and replacement with a diverse palate of native species. Project partners include the University of Washington Capstone program and the Restoration Ecology Network (UW-REN). Friends of North Creek Forest also seeks to increase direct volunteer stewardship by an additional 1,000, enabling them to address projects of a scale too large for UW-REN alone.

properties.Project Name: Connecting People to Our Marine & Estuary Waters Project
properties.Short Project Summary: Supports opportunities for people to connect with the fresh and saltwater environments of south Puget Sound, to learn more about its biology, geology, natural and human history, the threats to it, and ways each person can help protect and preserve the water on which all life is dependent. Activities include beach naturalists, school programs, a speakers series and a marine life discovery center.

properties.Project Name: Kids Making a Difference NOW!
properties.Short Project Summary: Supports an environmental science curriculum promoting stewardship of Puget Sound killer whales and their habitat. Killer Whale Tales� curriculum teaches school children about orcas� complex individual and social behaviors and the human impacts on the species in order to capture children�s attention and imaginations, providing a gateway for teaching about environmental field science and the importance of environmental conservation. Activities include interactive storytelling that leads to the behavioral/conservation biology, and participation in experiential science and role-playing activities based on actual Puget Sound orca field studies. These �games� enable students to practice field science in the classroom; introduce students to the most recent orca research; demonstrate how human actions impact the marine ecosystem and orca populations and show students what they can do to help correct these issues. Students also become advocates for the Puget Sound and the orcas by taking home KWT�s �Kids Making A Difference-Now!� and �Stormwater Busters� conservation worksheets, which chart families� environmental footprint and provide a plan to diminish their impact.

properties.Project Name: Lower Soos Creek, Green River Watershed Project
properties.Short Project Summary: Supports the continued implementation of an extensive water quality and habitat restoration project adjacent to Soos Creek near its confluence with the Green River. This project expands on an existing EPA grant that King County Department of Natural Resources and Parks received to plant native vegetation along Soos Creek to improve water quality and address the 303(d) listing for temperature and dissolved oxygen. To date, Middle Green River Coalition has planted over 3,000 native willow and cottonwood stakes in the riparian zone and extensively maintained these planting sites to ensure plant survival. In 2013, MGRC expanded these efforts to include adjacent properties along the Green River on Washington State Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW) land. Both Soos Creek and the Green River support Chinook and steelhead salmon spawning and rearing.

properties.Organization Name: Stanwood High School Natural Resources Class
properties.Project Name: Stillaguamish River Clean Water Project
properties.Short Project Summary: Supports the installation and maintenance of trash receptacles in the Church Creek area of the Stillaguamish River, including removal of trash and debris in the immediate area surrounding the trash receptacle. The project is part of an overall watershed stewardship effort led by local high school students to collaborate with Washington State University Extension, the Stillaguamish tribe and surrounding school districts to conduct riparian restoration, raise and release salmon eggs into Church Creek, and teach elementary school students about the salmon lifecycle and habitat.

properties.Project Name: Art for Learning Watershed Science
properties.Short Project Summary: Supports expanded programming for �Art for Learning Watershed Science,� a collaborative and integrated approach for learning about water, watersheds, and species of the Puget Sound produced by Skagit Conservation Education Alliance and Padilla Bay Foundation. Workshops are free for families or low-fee designed specifically for adults and teachers earning Teacher Clock hours. The existing program has a successful two-year track record with young and older age groups. This grant would support expanded programming to appeal to teens and young adults between 13 � 24 years old and help them express themselves in creative mediums including radio broadcasts, performances, poetry, painting, drawing, video, 3D work, and cartography. Learning outcomes, performances and radio broadcasts from the expanded program for youth will be shared in schools and at public events, conferences and regional summits.

properties.Organization Name: Friends Of Newberry Hill Heritage Park
properties.Project Name: Water Mapping Project
properties.Short Project Summary: To map water courses in the Chico Watershed headwaters and correct existing state maps that currently show water courses in the wrong location. These fish-bearing waters and buffers will be established, and forest practices permits will be issued based on map data. Volunteers will ground truth locations using GPS and submit data to a professional surveyor for mapping and submission to the Washington State DNR FPAR�s system.

properties.Project Name: Clear To The Sound
properties.Short Project Summary: Supports technical analysis, community outreach and legal advocacy to ensure full analysis of the impacts of gravel mining and rock quarries in the headwaters of Dickerson Creek and the Gorst Creek watershed � an ecologically sensitive area containing salmon and beaver habitat which drains to Dyes Inlet and Puget Sound.

properties.Organization Name: Sierra Club, South King County Group
properties.Project Name: South King County Group Soos Creek Park Restoration Project
properties.Short Project Summary: Supports the restoration of Soos Creek Park by organizing at least two restoration events per year in coordination with the King County Department of Natural Resources and Parks. Activities will include enhancing the park by supporting expansion of the park and the creation of buffer areas, and working with the Bonneville Power Administration to manage vegetation on its right of way through portions of the park, improving wildlife values and public recreational opportunities.

properties.Project Name: Inspire Stewardship of Puget Sound Waters
properties.Short Project Summary: Inspire increased stewardship of Puget Sound marine and estuary life through:1. South Sound Estuarium, a marine life discovery center2. "Meet Us At the Beach", volunteer naturalist interpretation at local public access beaches.3. Pier Peer at Boston Harbor Marina, nighttime underwater viewing of marine life4. Discovery Speaker Series, fall/winter marine/estuary/water quality topics5. Connecting Youth to Nature, on the beach, in the Estuarium or classroom6, South Sound Naturalists - volunteers at tide pool areas of watershed model

properties.Project Name: Volunteer Program Implementation
properties.Short Project Summary: Supports restoration of a 260-acre urban estuary adjacent to the State Capital, and further expansion implementation of a volunteer-based community outreach program � working towards goal of 100 trained and committed volunteers to engage the community in restoring the Deschutes Estuary.

properties.Project Name: Phase 2 Launch Rodney Goes Green
properties.Short Project Summary: Rodney Goes Green is a youth engagement and environmental awareness program delivered in close cooperation with Tacoma Public Schools that educates students about how their behaviors and activities impact the environment, contribute to polluted runoff and affect Puget Sound water quality. Through award-winning videos, a Go Green video game and associated curricula, the program helps young people understand how their activities impact Puget Sound water quality and teaches them how to reduce polluted runoff.

properties.Project Name: Carpenter Creek Estuary Restoration and Monitoring Program
properties.Short Project Summary: The Carpenter Creek estuary system, in the midst of Kingston�s Urban Growth Area, provides more than 30 acres of high quality habitat in a crucial location for migrating salmonids. On the West side of Puget Sound, it is part of the critical natural habitat that balances the urbanization of the East side of the Sound, but also faces threats from local population growth. The recently replaced undersized culvert at the mouth of the estuary was creating unnatural flow rates that hindered fish passage, created scour holes, and trapped sediment in the estuary. In 2012, the culvert was replaced with a 90 foot bridge, the Stillwaters Fish Passage. The second part of this restoration is to replace another culvert in the middle of the estuary. This grant will support the related monitoring program, which is critical to the evaluation of its success and in determining further restoration needs, and will also train and educate local citizens on the importance of watershed protection.

properties.Project Name: Experiential Learning In Environmental Science
properties.Short Project Summary: Supports an experiential learning-based environmental science education program for K-12 students serving students in Snohomish and King counties. Activities will include teaching concepts and skills in environmental science monitoring of water quality, stream health, and forest ecology to students; increasing college student involvement; improving the quality and availability of equipment and supplies for fieldwork; and building community awareness of programs and the results of the students� work.

properties.Project Name: Whidbey Island Impaired Waters
properties.Short Project Summary: Whidbey Island streams all terminate in Puget Sound, and there are swimming and shellfish harvest closures around the island. This project will contribute to the water quality project in the Maxwelton Watershed, and the restoration and conversion of the recently acquired 45-acre wetland near Freeland into a public Watershed Science Center.

properties.Project Name: Boise Creek-Treat Riparian Restoration
properties.Short Project Summary: The Middle Green River Coalition (MGRC) requests $10,000 to support Phase I of the Boise Creek-Treat Riparian Restoration project along approximately 450 feet of Boise Creek.  MGRC board members met with private property owners David and Joanne Treat to assess the site and discuss a potential riparian restoration project on their 6.62 acre parcel that borders Boise Creek in southeast King County.  The Treats responded with enthusiasm and welcome assistance to manage out-of-control invasive vegetation that has overtaken the riparian area on their property.  This reach of stream provides primary spawning and rearing habitat for three Endangered Species Act (ESA)-listed fish species: White River spring and fall Chinook, steelhead salmon, and bull trout.The project site currently supports well-established Himalayan blackberry (Rubus discolor), and to a lesser extent reed canary grass (Phalaris arundinacea) and other non-native vegetation that collectively dominate a 50 foot width along approximately 450 feet of the Boise Creek riparian zone.  The Phase I project scope includes using organic methods to remove robust stands of Himalayan blackberries and other invasive plants within the riparian zone while preserving existing native trees and shrubs, and then placing temporary barrier fabric where needed to discourage regrowth.  Areas not covered by fabric will be planted with native trees and vegetation.  Phase I will be completed within twelve-months.  In Phase II, the site will be monitored regularly for two to three years to manually remove invasive regrowth and ensure long-term plant survival.  When deemed appropriate by MGRC's restoration specialist, the fabric will be removed and the areas planted with native trees and vegetation.  MGRC�s partners include King County, King Conservation District, Green River Community College, other nonprofit organizations, private and public landowners, and volunteers.

properties.Project Name: Art for Learning Watershed Science - Connecting with Teens
properties.Short Project Summary: The goal of this film-making project will be to provide an opportunity for film students to connect with student environmental groups.  By doing so, we hope to create a learning opportunity for both groups of high school aged students.  The environmentally oriented students will be exposed to creating a watershed stewardship film targeted toward a non-environmentally focused audience.  The film students will be exposed to environmental concerns, hopefully raising their own environmental awareness. Particular emphasis will be placed on how to communicate a scientific message to a non-scientific audience. Local high school film-making instructors will be solicited for student participation. SCEA will then connect the students with local organizations creating watershed protection and water quality improvement projects (e.g. rain garden installation, riparian area restoration). The resulting video will be used by SCEA for promoting watershed stewardship and distributed through several avenues.

properties.Project Name: Killer Whale Tales- Kids Making a Difference Now/ Stormbusters
properties.Short Project Summary: Killer Whale Tales engages children by using interactive storytelling, immersive hands-on science activities, and measurable conservation actions that plant the seeds for a life-long relationship with the Southern Resident Killer Whales and the Puget Sound habitat that supports us all.Students are fascinated by orcas� complex individual and social behaviors. When they learn about the species, they begin to care about it and become interested in learning what they can do to help protect it. This knowledge opens a tremendous gateway for teaching science�which teachers love! The curriculum invites students to be scientists; they develop hypotheses, practice field observation using current scientific data, learn to interpret data, and brainstorm ways to decrease human impacts on orcas. Our program also provides a gateway for making conservation and civic responsibility meaningful to students and their families. Our classroom and take-home activities foster informed decision making as students explore their relationship and responsibility to the world and the whales around them.Additionally, we value the quantitative results we receive from our participants.  We have hard numbers and data going back to 2004 that statistically demonstrates the efficacy of our program.  Whether it is how much water a school saved, or how students increased their "orca IQ", we monitor it and use it in our future decision making.

properties.Project Name: Whale Scout
properties.Short Project Summary: Every fall and winter endangered killer whales enter the waters of Puget Sound in search of prey. Whale Scouts line the shorelines at local parks, assisting the public in sighting whales. They also teach people what threats whales face, how to help, and inspire protection by encouraging the public to become stewards of the environment. By transforming the awe and amazement of seeing killer whales into action, Whale Scout is restoring Puget Sound.The goal of Whale Scout is to recover threatened and endangered whales in the Salish Sea ecosystem through salmon habitat restoration projects and everyday stewardship activities. Volunteers are equipped with identifying vests and weather-proof educational materials to illustrate how much habitat on land is required for the lifecycles of salmon, and in turn, whales. Infographics also illustrate how chemicals from our homes many miles from the ocean work their way through water treatment plants into rivers, Puget Sound, and then finally up the food chain into killer whales. Whale Scouts are quick to offer opportunities to become stewards of the whales with suggestions like limiting the use of harsh cleaning products and pesticides, or conserving water and electricity. Additionally, we invite the public to join us at quarterly "Helpin' Out" events where we partner with local groups to restore salmon habitat. Being outside whale watching and restoring habitats teaches us the inter-connectedness of our ecosystem�s waters and the importance of every small piece of habitat, as well as the role it plays in filtering the water which is the lifeblood of our rivers, streams, salmon, and killer whales. This year's team of 13 volunteers is already equipped and doing great work throughout Puget Sound. At high traffic locations such as Alki Point, a single volunteer can connect with 30 people per hour. We are requesting funding to continue and expand our volunteer team and habitat restoration partnerships in 2015.

properties.Project Name: Down on the Farm: Least Toxic Solutions for Snohomish County
properties.Short Project Summary: The 2013 Grassroots grant awarded to Horses for Clean Water (HCW) partnered with Snohomish Conservation District (SCD) to initiate the Sound Horsekeeping program in Snohomish County. This program resulted in the implementation of Best Management Practices (BMPs) by horse owners at an even higher rate than expected. Down on the Farm: Least Toxic Solutions for Snohomish County continues that partnership but expands the audience to include commercial and non-commercial livestock/ag producers and focuses the message on chemical use reduction. In Horses for Clean Water�s 17+ years of service we have noted pasture management is a difficult and complex BMP for horse owners to adopt and implement. Additionally, pasture management classes are our biggest draw and horse owners report weed control as a major concern. Traditionally, the solution for most is to spray herbicides. Many do so without realizing there are least-toxic alternatives and that pesticide misuse causes negative impacts. Clearly horse owners need more education on proper pasture management and a deeper understanding of the impacts herbicides have on water quality and invertebrates--as well as education on safe alternatives for managing weeds and pests. Horses for Clean Water proposes to hold four events targeting chemical use reduction among horse and livestock owners as well as agricultural producers on the following topics: weed and pasture management, pollinator/beneficial insect conservation, and native plants and wildlife enhancement combined with least-toxic pest control. The goal will be for audience members to reduce chemical use and provide wildlife enhancement on their properties as well as use native plants to help reduce mud, runoff and erosion. Participants that implement these BMPs will reduce non-point pollution in Central Puget Sound by reducing runoff of sediments, nutrients and fecal coliform from overgrazed pastures, and chemicals from fertilizer, herbicide or pesticide use/misuse.

properties.Project Name: Building Grassroots Help to Restore the North Creek Watershed
properties.Short Project Summary: We are seeking to improve water quality in a Chinook salmon bearing stream, North Creek, by restoring the ability of North Creek Forest to naturally filter surface water from upland neighborhoods and by controlling erosion. Currently, much of the runoff is piped across the forest. This grant would be used to build the capacity to restore the forest so the pipes can eventually be removed. This will be our first year addressing direct streamside erosion and our fourth year of collaborative restoration efforts with the University of Washington Bothell�s Restoration Ecology Network (UW-REN) students.

properties.Project Name: Hazel Valley Rain Gardens
properties.Short Project Summary: Convert 3 drainage ditches on City Right-of Way into 1 rain garden and 2 bioswales. The 3 ditches drain a total of 28.62 acres.  Remove sod/soil 6" deep X 5' wide in ditch #1 of 57', in ditch #2 of 102' and ditch #3 of 125'.  Sod/soil to be excavated and transported to proper disposal site by licensed, bonded and Insured contractors.  Quarry rock to be placed appropriately by City direction as retainers and debris filters.  Erosion materials on site to be used as directed by the City Inspectors.  Amended soil added to ditches per WSU Extension Handbook.  Purchased plants/bioswale seed installed as suggested in WSU Handbook in zones 1,2&3. Plants to be planted by volunteers from Sustainable Burien, Weed Warriors, Neighbors, Environmental Science Center, Students and Parents of Hazel Valley Elementary, King County Master Gardeners and Stewardship Partners.  Planting Plan to be approved by the City of Burien.  Hazel Valley Elementary will use the project as a learning opportunity for the 6th grade science requirements and will take the students to the site (4 blocks away) to see how the rain gardens/bioswales are implemented during the construction phase.  After the gardens are installed a garden club will be formed to help the adjoining property owners maintain the gardens.  The City may use this project as a model for additional rain garden/bioswale projects.  We hope to convert another 300 ft of drainage ditch in this drainage area to a rain garden/bioswale when able.The excavation contractor is a retired King County Employee and has worked on several restoration projects.  The City of Burien will over see all work and materials to ensure that their requirements are attained and that the system will function properly.  The City will be responsible for up grading the road shoulder and the road side of the drainage ditch.

properties.Project Name: Nisqually Reach Aquatic Reserve
properties.Short Project Summary: The Nisqually Reach Nature Center proposes to continue its work fostering community involvement and citizen science research in South Puget Sound.  As a part of this work we have fostered two Citizen Stewardship Committees in support of the Nisqually Reach Aquatic Reserve.  This proposal would allow us to continue funding a coordinator position to support these efforts

properties.Project Name: Shinglemill Creek Stormwater Project: community science for clean waters and healthy salmon
properties.Short Project Summary: Shinglemill Creek forms one of Vashon Island�s largest watersheds (King County, central Puget Sound).  Clear flowing water, large old cedars, and protected forest trails make Shinglemill Creek a popular outdoor destination. However, the beauty of this place is deceptive. Since 2001 people have seen fewer salmon here.  Just this season the Vashon Nature Center (VNC) Salmon Watcher program documented a possible case of pre-spawning mortality in coho. Aquatic invertebrate data reveal that Shinglemill Creek scores lower than other major watersheds on the island for biological integrity and on level with many urban streams in the county.  In 2014, VNC partnered with the Vashon Groundwater Protection Committee (VGPWC) and Vashon School District (VSD) to explore why Shinglemill Creek was scoring so poorly for health. Students worked with VNC scientists to sort over 700 invertebrates from Shinglemill.  What they found surprised them. In this rural creek, invertebrate assemblages showed indicators of stormwater run-off impacts! Student findings changed VGWPC priorities and galvanized community support for stewardship action to curb run-off from Vashon town into Shinglemill. In 2015, a grassroots effort involving VNC, Sustainable Vashon, VGWPC, Vashon Maury Island Land Trust and VSD will begin the first step in curbing polluted run-off by installing carwash kits in a parking lot used for student fundraiser carwashes and tracking the effect of this change on creek health.  We are seeking support to involve students in solving stormwater issues and to enlist community members and students as citizen scientists in tracking effects of changes in stormwater management through our Scientists in Schools and Salmon Watchers programs.  We invite the Rose Foundation to partner with us in this exciting effort to increase community awareness of this largely invisible issue and to galvanize community support to stop polluted run-off from reaching Puget Sound.

properties.Project Name: Water Watchers
properties.Short Project Summary: The Water Watchers program will train citizens and students to monitor basic water quality parameters in Puget Sound watersheds. Program goals include engaging volunteers, students, and local groups, providing environmental education, working to improve water quality, and increasing public awareness and action. The Sno-King Watershed Council will coordinate this project with local environmental organizations, schools, and jurisdictions. A core project team will administer the program, provide training, equipment management, volunteer coordination and mentorship, and information sharing. This is a pilot program designed to expand as additional groups and volunteers are incorporated. Volunteers will use standardized test equipment to monitor water temperature, pH, dissolved oxygen, turbidity, & conductivity. They will also assess benthic invertebrates & physical stream characteristics including sediment, habitat complexity, & canopy closure. The project team will acquire test kits and conduct training for volunteers and students. Trained volunteers will train others, check out kits, conduct tests, and return the kits. Students will conduct testing under the tutelage of trained volunteers. Data will be collected regularly from July 2015 to June 2017 on specific streams in the Cedar-Sammamish-Lake Washington watershed. Target streams include Bear Creek, Little Bear Creek, North Creek, Horse Creek, Parr Creek, Little Swamp Creek, Swamp Creek, Lyon Creek, MacAleer Creek, and Thornton Creek. These streams represent a range of sizes and levels of urbanization. Monitoring data will be compiled and published on the Sno-King Watershed Council website. Maps of watersheds will show monitoring sites, with links to monitoring data collected by volunteers, and by local governments and agencies.  Information will additionally be shared via public presentations, social media, and targeted communications to local elected officials. See project Work Plan for additional details.

properties.Project Name: Watershed Health and Youth
properties.Short Project Summary: The Deschutes Estuary Restoration Team (DERT) is a 501c3 nonprofit organization and our mission is to restore and protect the Deschutes River Watershed as it flows to South Puget Sound and the Salish Sea.  DERT's first objective is to remove the small dam at the mouth of the Deschutes River.  The dam was built in 1951 to form Capitol Lake with the function of a sediment reservoir and reflecting pool for Washington State's legislative done.  DERT is working on dam removal and estuary restoration at the policy, education and scientific level. DERT has developed an education and outreach strategy that encompasses estuary education, watershed health and all of our volunteers who form the "Estuary Stewards" team.   A primary target for volunteer education are youth to ensure a healthy watershed for future citizens.  It is DERT's belief that youth need to be educated and trained to understand, appreciate, restore and protect our precious fresh and marine waters, fish and wildlife species and the watershed they depend on for life. To that end, DERT is developing a Watershed Health and Youth (WHY) training program to give young people a chance to ask questions, learn about ecosystem health and develop their "sense of place" within the Deschutes watershed as a direct link to South Puget Sound and the Salish Sea.   This understanding is critical to the health and vitality of this precious ecosystem for future generations. WHY youth will work with DERT's Science Team and study the Deschutes watershed and all of its attributes.  They will take monthly field trips and work in the classroom. They will learn about healthy, functioning ecosystems and identify recreational opportunities within the watershed to nurture a broader sense of understanding and public enjoyment.  They will also learn about the economic opportunities that their watershed provides, and how to sustain the ecosystem while enjoying the benefits of living, working and recreating in this 51 mile river basin.

properties.Project Name: Carpenter Creek Estuary Restoration
properties.Short Project Summary: As you heard last year, the Carpenter Creek estuary system, in the midst of Kingston�s Urban Growth Area, provides more than 30 acres of high quality habitat in a crucial Puget Sound location for migrating salmonids. The undersized culvert at the mouth of the estuary had been creating unnatural flow rates that hindered fish passage, created scour holes, and trapped sediment in the estuary. In 2012, the culvert was replaced with a 90� bridge, which the County named the Stillwaters Fish Passage. Phase 2 of this restoration is to replace another culvert in the middle of the estuary, which, we are thrilled to say, will happen in 2017! The MONITORING PROGRAM of this restoration project is critical to evaluation of its success & in demonstrating need for further restoration here and elsewhere around the Sound. The Monitoring Program is citizen-scientist based, with oversight and guidance from the professionals on the Stillwaters monitoring team. With help from the Rose Foundation (thank you so much!), we were able to supervise two dozen volunteers for over 400 hours donated to monitoring in the last 6 months of 2015. EXPANDED EDUCATION: Stillwaters uses this monitoring program not only for protecting the estuary and documenting the restoration work, but also to train and educate our local citizens on the importance of watershed protection, and to create advocates for preservation of natural spaces. We are very excited about the expanded use the monitoring program as training ground for undergraduate interns and graduate research students from Western Washington University and the University of Washington. This is a proposal to support the monitoring program and corresponding community and college education, which receives no other public funding.

properties.Organization Name: Cherry Point Aquatic Reserve Citizen  Stewardship Committee
properties.Project Name: Cherry Point Stewardship Project
properties.Short Project Summary: The Cherry Point Aquatic Reserve Citizen Stewardship Committee will raise the profile of the Cherry Point Aquatic Reserve, contribute to scientific surveys which help define the resources of the reserve, and ensure that development projects that affect the reserve are scientifically scrutinized and carefully vetted.

properties.Organization Name: Fidalgo Bay Aquatic Reserve Citizen Stewardship Committee
properties.Project Name: Fidalgo Bay Science and Stewardship Project
properties.Short Project Summary: The Fidalgo Bay Science and Stewardship project aims to elevate the profile of Fidalgo Bay and improve its water quality. This will be done through engaging the public and conducting outreach and education about life in the bay and threats to it. Special topics will include citizen science surveys of intertidal life and forage fish, and the threat of stormwater pollution.

properties.Project Name: HeyDuwamish.org
properties.Short Project Summary: We are building a grassroots mapping tool to inform, engage, and empower communities to take action for their environmental health. Our pilot scenario is at the Duwamish River Superfund site, where our volunteer team of dedicated software engineers have launched a demo map called 'Hey, Duwamish!' Our project website is: http://heyduwamish.org. Community members and stakeholders can share ideas, photos, comments, and questions on a detailed interactive map of the 23 year long cleanup. This will enforce transparency, accountability, and community engagement to maximize the $342 million investment mandated by the EPA. We are building a new kind of partnership network that spans the globe. Our work was inspired by a group of civic hackers in Buenos Aires, Argentina who call themselves GarageLab, and built a community monitoring system for the heavily polluted Matanza-Riachuelo River Basin. We saw what they made here: http://quepasariachuelo.org.ar and asked ourselves why this kind of tool doesn't exist for pollution along the Green-Duwamish watershed. We organized online meetings between GarageLab and the Duwamish River Cleanup Coalition, and agreed to form a collaboration to advance new practices in mapping complex socio-environmental conflict scenarios. The result is a new kind of group process called "collective cartography." Here is the theory: Geographic maps are often read-only, and limit themselves by showing "what is" rather than "what is possible." By exploring new ground at the intersection of community engagement plus environmental health, we can bridge the gap by combining geographic information systems with collective knowledge for positive change. Our coalition is founded on principles of free and open source software, where supporters can freely adopt and contribute to our work. This will encourage community-driven development toward a public codebase that can evolve and be reused with other community mapping software projects.

properties.Project Name: Clean Water and Green Infrastructure
Puget Sound Spill Kit Program
properties.Short Project Summary: Many drains from businesses flow directly into a local waterway. If there�s a spill, it�s the business� responsibility to clean it up. ECOSS provides free spill kits, custom spill plans and training so businesses know how to quickly deal with potentially toxic runoff.

properties.Project Name: General Support
properties.Short Project Summary: The Mountains to Sound Greenway Trust leads and inspires action to conserve and enhance the landscape from Seattle across the Cascade Mountains to Central Washington, ensuring a long-term balance between people and nature.

properties.Project Name: Hylebos Watershed-Scale Restoration Planning
properties.Short Project Summary: In 2016 EarthCorps developed a comprehensive Hylebos Watershed Plan. The plan creates a vision that can inspire and educate adjacent property owners, community members, and other nearby stakeholders of the importance of the Hylebos watershed. This report adopts a holistic management approach in order to identify, prioritize and act on behalf of ecological and human health in the Hylebos watershed.

properties.Project Name: Bog to Bay; Stormwater Pollution Solutions in My Neighborhood
properties.Short Project Summary: Bog to Bay�is a collective impact�initiative�to embed stormwater education in the core curriculum of local schools by using real-world content such as stormwater policy, science, engineering, and performance measures to drive project-based learning that results in measurable reductions in polluted stormwater runoff in Elliot Bay and Puget Sound. This innovative approach integrates two objectives: (1) evaluate�sustainable community conditions as both measures of progress and resources for learning; and (2) empower�students, teachers and residents to solve community challenges through collective, intergenerational project management. The geography for this project includes the school neighborhoods within the Longfellow Creek Watershed from the Roxhill Bog to Elliot Bay, as well as the combined sewer overflow (CSO) basins of (1) Delridge/Highland Park, (2) Barton/Fauntleroy, and (3) South Park in the lower Duwamish River.

properties.Project Name: Long Term Fish Use of the Elwha River Nearshore
properties.Short Project Summary: CWI coordinates the Elwha Nearshore Consortium, a group of scientists, managers, and citizens dedicated to understanding and promoting the nearshore restoration associated with the upcoming dam removals. The Consortium has identified a set of high priority needs to address prior to and during dam removal. Since nearshore restoration will only be partially restored the group has determined additional information is needed to understand what further actions are needed to achieve ecosystem restoration in the nearshore. Priorities include developing and implementing a nearshore restoration action plan, documenting long term fish use of the Elwha nearshore, defining the role feeder bluffs play in sediment dynamics of the Elwha nearshore, and understanding linkages between hydrodynamics and ecological function of the Elwha estuary and shorelines.

properties.Project Name: Puget Sound Stewards - Duwamish
properties.Short Project Summary: Puget Sound Stewards�are committed volunteers of all ages who are trained in the management of nearshore restoration sites, and work to ensure their success.�EarthCorps deploys teams of Stewards to sites�along estuaries, rivers and beaches in�the cities of Seattle, Tukwila, Edmonds, and Everett.

properties.Project Name: Washington Sustainable Agriculture Campaign
properties.Short Project Summary: The Western Environmental Law Center uses the power of the law to safeguard the wildlife, wildlands, and communities of the American West. We envision a West with thriving, resilient wildlands, waters, and wildlife; a region powered by clean, renewable energy; and communities that are rooted in an ethic of conservation. WELC works close to the ground, with offices in Oregon, Washington, Montana, and New Mexico. As a public interest law firm, WELC does not charge clients and partners for services, but relies instead on charitable gifts from individuals, families, and foundations to accomplish our mission. WELC integrates national policies and regional perspective with the local knowledge of our 185+ partner groups to implement smart and appropriate place-based solutions.

properties.Project Name: Citizen Stewardship for Clean Water
properties.Short Project Summary: We promote sustainable communities and protect the health of northwestern Washington�s people and ecosystems through application of science, education, advocacy and action. Our vision is to help people in northwestern Washington live satisfying lives in accord with the ecosystem we depend on � generation after generation.

properties.Project Name: General Support
properties.Short Project Summary: DRCC/TAG is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization involved in all aspects of the cleanup of the Duwamish River, working to ensure the cleanup meets community standards by restoring environmental health and protecting the fishers and families who use the river as well as reflecting the priorities, values and will of the people who live and work in the region.  The organization was founded in 2001 by community, neighborhood, environmental, tribal, and small business organizations that came together to serve as EPA�s Community Advisory Group. These organizations continue to guide and shape the work of DRCC/TAG as the Advisory Council.

properties.Project Name: Nisqually Land Trust Riparian Forest Restoration Initiative
properties.Short Project Summary: The Nisqually Land Trust is an independent, private, nongovernmental organization incorporated in 1989 and federally recognized as a 501(c)(3) nonprofit corporation in 1990. Our mission is to acquire and manage critical lands to permanently benefit the water, wildlife, and people of the Nisqually River Watershed.

properties.Project Name: Duwamish Alive! Watershed Habitat Restoration & Community Stewardship
properties.Short Project Summary: Duwamish Alive collaborates with community, municipalities, non-profits and businesses within the Duwamish River Watershed to preserve and enhance habitat for people and wildlife, towards improving the health of the Puget Sound.

properties.Project Name: Legacy Watersheds: Public-Private Low Impact Development Solutions for Puget Sound
General Support
properties.Short Project Summary: After 35 years, the Washington Toxics Coalition became Toxic-Free Future to better represent the organization�s hopeful vision for how the world should be for our families and environment. Toxic-Free Future advocates for the use of safer products, chemicals, and practices through advanced research, advocacy, grassroots organizing, and consumer engagement to ensure a healthier tomorrow.

properties.Project Name: General Support
Ecosystem and Water Quality Advocacy through Watershed Restoration in Olympia
properties.Short Project Summary: We are a growing group of Olympia citizens, businesses and environmental organizations who propose to restore and re-wild the Olympia Shoreline and associated riparian corridors such that this connected ecosystem becomes quality habitat, enabling our region's wildlife to persist and thrive for future generations. We are driven by our understanding of the intrinsic value of all creatures in our ecosystem. We are united in our value of biodiversity and believe that our human community is enriched by and defined by our relationship to the wilderness in our midst.

properties.Project Name: Langley Middle School Oceanography, Smith & Minor Islands Aquatic Reserve Citizen Science/Outreach
properties.Short Project Summary: Whidbey Watershed Stewards is a non-profit 501c(3) corporation working with the Whidbey Island community to promote watershed stewardship, habitat enhancement, and environmental education for all ages.  Whidbey Watershed Stewards promotes nearshore and watershed health by linking water, land, wildlife and people on Whidbey Island through education, research, and restoration.

properties.Project Name: 2015-16 Regional Stormwater Monitoring Program (RSMP)
properties.Short Project Summary: The Bainbridge Beach Naturalists create opportunities for the public to explore our Bainbridge Island beaches and nearshore areas with trained naturalists. During low tide events, we are on the beach looking for the amazing sea life that shares our shores with us. Bainbridge Beach Naturalists also provide beach monitoring for organizations such as the Bainbridge Island Land Trust and the City of Bainbridge Island. This work enables us to observe changes in beach composition, elevation, and variety and density of species on our beaches.  We have also worked on the mussel cage program with Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife to assess pollutants in stormwater runoff.

properties.Organization Name: Save Habitat and Diversity of Wetlands Org
properties.Project Name: General Support
properties.Short Project Summary: SHADOW Lake Nature Preserve stewards critical habitat, increases access to green spaces, and provides inclusive environmental education to cultivate a land use ethic throughout the Puget Sound Region.

properties.Project Name: Kids Making a Difference Now/Whale Scouts
properties.Short Project Summary: Killer Whale Tales is a 501 (c) 3 environmental education program that uses storytelling and field based science to inspire students to take an active role in the conservation of Pacific Northwest killer whales and their habitat.

properties.Project Name: Community Involvement in the Restoration of the Sammamish River at Wayne Golf Course
properties.Short Project Summary: Our mission is to preserve the Wayne Golf Course land, situated along the Sammamish River and Burke-Gilman trail, for recreation, education, and fish and wildlife habitat. We are working with the public, the_City of Bothell, King County, the State of Washington, and Forterra_to turn the Wayne Golf Course_property into a park for generations to come.

properties.Project Name: Aquatic Reserve Program
properties.Short Project Summary: The Nisqually Reach Nature Center proposes to engage citizen stewards in research and education outreach in South Puget Sound communities.  Citizen scientists will collect data on active waterfowl breeding sites and forage fish spawning beaches in the Nisqually Reach Aquatic Reserve and report that information to Aquatic Reserve managers, state and federal agencies, and the public.  As the site proponent, the Nature Center staff will motivate and organize volunteers to accomplish this effort.  Citizens will be engaged in the long-term stewardship of these aquatic resources.

properties.Project Name: Hylebos Watershed Community-Based Restoration
properties.Short Project Summary: Hylebos Creek is a salmon-bearing stream located between the busy urban centers of Seattle and Tacoma, directly under the flight path of jets landing at the Seattle-Tacoma airport; it crosses under Interstate 5 and two state highways before emptying into Tacoma's Commencement Bay. Despite all the traffic and sprawling strip mall developments, parts of the watershed host surprisingly intact forests, attractive grassy parks, bluffs overlooking central Puget Sound, and even a rare peat bog that is lush and teaming with life. Communities along Hylebos Creek are coming together to protect and connect the bits of nature along the creek. Their work helps save salmon, birds, and other wildlife, keeps dirt and pollution out of Puget Sound, and provides essential green oases for the diverse residents of these growing suburbs.

properties.Project Name: Sound Horsekeeping to Protect Puget Sound
properties.Short Project Summary: Horses for Clean Water and Snohomish Conservation District will work with 11 Puget Sound Conservation Districts to expand the Sound Horsekeeping program throughout the Puget Sound region. The project will focus on training farm and resource planners on promoting equine best management practices (BMPs) through the voluntary, incentive-based Sound Horsekeeping Program, which was piloted in Snohomish County with a 2013 Rose Foundation Grant. This regional approach will help counties without adequate resources to market the program to their constituents with a 'train the trainer' approach. Promotion of BMPs by the equine community will be facilitated by brochures, a series of webinars and the Better Ground website. Better Ground is a marketing/branding program currently being adopted by Puget Sound conservation districts to help their clients find resources in their efforts to improve their farms and protect natural resources.

properties.Project Name: Science Connects: discovering our role in a healthy Puget Sound
properties.Short Project Summary: Science Connects gets people outside watching, feeling, and understanding the forces that shape life and promote health in local watersheds. We invite the entire community, from children through elders, to track salmon in our creeks, analyze stream bugs, and (new in 2016!) monitor beach life. Working with scientists participants are inspired to take action for a healthy Sound.  We cultivate partnerships with a variety of groups to develop quality citizen-science projects that have real impact on local management decisions. By integrating a variety of citizen-science opportunities under one goal�discovering our role in a healthy Puget Sound, we discover links between watersheds and nearshore ecosystems and track the often invisible impacts that flow between them. We invite continued Rose Foundation support to broaden our suite of local partnerships and develop internal capacity to lead a powerful citizen-science program for healthy waters on Vashon- Maury Island (King County, WRIA 9).

properties.Project Name: Donkey Creek Outreach, Education & Action Project (PHASE 3)
properties.Short Project Summary: The Donkey Creek Outreach, Education & Action Project aims to inspire stewardship for our local creeks and estuaries among adults, students and families in the South Puget Sound. Funding is designated for the third phase of this project and will allow the continuation of important public and student tours of a recently restored salmon-bearing creek, as well as the continued collection of biodiversity data that has taken place since the restoration was completed. Funding from the Rose Foundation is crucial in the continued success of this three year project by replacing funding that is unavailable until 2017.

properties.Project Name: BOG to BAY - Stormwater Pollution Solutions in My Neighborhood
properties.Short Project Summary: The goal of the Bog to Bay Project is to embed stormwater education in the core curriculum of local schools by using real-world content to drive project-based learning.  This long-term, multi-partner, multi-funder strategy will result in measurable reductions in polluted stormwater runoff in Puget Sound. Our unique approach features the integration of increased curriculum relevance in the classroom with measurable stewardship actions in the community. This proposal will implement and amplify the program elements we have piloted at three schools in Duwamish watershed: Denny Middle School, Chief Sealth High School and Holy Family Catholic School, all serving diverse student populations.  The Duwamish watershed supports salmon runs and includes the combined sewers overflow basins of Longfellow Creek (which flows from a historic bog and joins the Duwamish in a pipe) and the Lower Duwamish Waterway superfund site.

properties.Project Name: Bainbridge Island Beach Cleanup
properties.Short Project Summary: We are partnering with multiple organizations to inaugurate the first of what we hope is many Bainbridge-Island-wide shoreline cleanups. Our goal is to remove litter and refuse from all 53 miles of our Island's shoreline by engaging hundreds of participants from across our island's student, environmental, business, and nonprofit groups, and raising awareness about the critical issue of plastics and trash in our marine environment. We will be conducting this effort in partnership and concert with Ocean Conservancy's International Coastal Cleanup Day on September 17, 2016.

properties.Project Name: Carpenter Creek Estuary Restoration: Monitoring & Internship Program
properties.Short Project Summary: This model restoration project protects and restores over 30 acres of high quality habitat in a crucial Puget Sound location for migrating salmonids. The MONITORING PROGRAM of the restoration project is critical to evaluation of the project effectiveness and in creating a reference site for restoration elsewhere around the Sound.EDUCATION: We use this monitoring program to educate local citizens on the importance of watershed protection. We supervise  interns and graduate research students from Western Washington University and the University of Washington.A MODEL FOR OTHERS: In 2016-2017, we will focus on our use of collected data to educate the community. There is also a need to publish our data for the scientific community around Puget Sound. When we started the salt marsh monitoring, we had no reference sites to access for protocol or comparison. We see a big need to be a reference for other restoration of marshes around the Sound.

properties.Organization Name: People for an Environmentally Responsible Kenmore
properties.Project Name: LakeWashington.Us - A community map uniting all to protect and restore Lake Washington
properties.Short Project Summary: Our plan is to build an interactive community powered map to unite all who want to protect and restore Lake Washington and her surrounding watersheds. The north end of the Lake where we live is up against a number of powerful interests who are quickly trying to expand industrial, commercial, and residential developments without proper environmental review. The City is attempting to sidestep the SEPA review process, despite the fact that these proposed engineering plans will spread toxic contaminants such as dioxin into the lake and jeopardize critical Steelhead, Coho, and Chinook habitats.The community map will live at LakeWashington.Us and for the first time in history, unite all municipalities along the Lake�s shoreline with a common tool for information and restorative action.

properties.Project Name: Protecting The North Creek Watershed and Beyond
properties.Short Project Summary: The mission of Friends of North Creek Forest is to maintain and improve the ecological function of North Creek Forest through education, stewardship, and conservation in perpetuity. This 64 acre mature forest in Bothell helps to improve the water quality in nearby North Creek, a Chinook salmon bearing stream, by naturally filtering runoff from upland neighborhoods and protecting the steep slope from erosion. We request funding to support our Stewardship Program, which focuses on restoring North Creek Forest, while simultaneously engaging the community to participate in its care. We increase ecological literacy by engaging, supporting, training and inspiring volunteers of all ages, including college students and school children, to learn how to restore and protect North Creek Forest and beyond. Thank you for considering this proposal. Your support will help us continue to provide meaningful forest experiences and education for generations to come.

properties.Project Name: General Support
properties.Short Project Summary: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) designated the Duwamish River as a Superfund site in 2001, identifying it as one of the most toxic hazardous waste sites in the country. The Duwamish River Cleanup Coalition/Technical Advisory Group (DRCC/TAG) collaborates closely with the affected communities of Georgetown and South Park to address the health of these environmental justice communities and the health of Seattle�s only river. DRCC/TAG's focus is a comprehensive and health-protective cleanup of the Duwamish River that benefits the health of the fish, wildlife, and communities that rely on it for subsistence, recreation, employment, and cultural reasons.  This includes working with EPA to develop a transparent process for cleanup design; advocating to local governments to ensure maximum benefits from the cleanup and minimal impacts on the health and well-being of the communities; and continuing to ensure the community is informed and engaged in the stewardship of the river.

properties.Project Name: Student Stewardship Conservation Project
properties.Short Project Summary: The Student Stewardship Conservation Project is an immersive, comprehensive environmental education program designed to benefit both students and the natural environments they live in. Through a combination of education, scientific data collection and hands-on habitat restoration, 700 middle school students will work toward the study and protection of critical wetland and riparian habitat within the Puyallup River watershed. Participating students, primarily underserved rural students and students of color, will perform 2,800 hours of restoration work, including removing 1,500 square feet of invasive plants, planting 700 native plants and installing seven bird boxes at critical habitat sites. Students will also collect and analyze data to create an extensive and high-quality freshwater microplastic dataset. This project will simultaneously empower youth environmental stewards, amass a substantial dataset on aquatic plastics and directly benefit local waters through restoration actions.

properties.Project Name: An Agricultural Pollution Prevention Strategy to Save Salmon and Shellfish in Puget Sound
properties.Short Project Summary: In the Puget Sound, water pollution caused by industrial agriculture is degrading salmon habitat, water quality, and the Northwest's economy and culture. For the last 30 years, the State of Washington has spent billions of dollars on voluntary incentive programs designed to reduce agricultural pollution and to facilitate the recovery of salmon in the Puget Sound basin. These voluntary incentive programs, while a potentially useful tool, have largely failed to improve water quality and restore salmon and shellfish habitat, and a new, comprehensive approach is needed. Through strategic legal advocacy and policy work, the Western Environmental Law Center seeks to develop and implement an Agricultural Pollution Prevention Strategy to restore salmon and shellfish in Puget Sound.

properties.Project Name: Delridge Wetlands Restoration and Stewardship Project
properties.Short Project Summary: The Wetlands Restoration and Stewardship Project has five goals, which are:  1) to restore, preserve and protect a natural wetland habitat in Delridge.  2)  to re-forest portions of the site that buffer the delineated wetland.  3) to expand community supported agriculture by constructing two gardens and planting a small orchard to expand access to healthy fruits and vegetables to benefit community members. 4) to partner with K-8 STEM School, Arbor Heights Elementary and Denny Middle School to create environmental stewards of all ages, and 5) to grow support for investing in green infrastructure systems, creating a replicable model for other communities within the City of Seattle. With this project we will enhance the natural wetland, effectively manage stormwater runoff using bio-remedition, and significantly increase hydrology, cool and filter contaminated stormwater that crosses the street coming from neighboring yards and an adjacent hillside before flowing into Longfellow Creek.

properties.Project Name: Hey Duwamish! - open technology and community engagement for the Green-Duwamish Watershed
properties.Short Project Summary: Hey Duwamish is a community monitoring platform designed to connect stakeholders and empower those most affected by pollution in the Duwamish Valley. Our open source mapping platform allows community members to report concerns, share ideas, ask questions, and stay up to date on important information happening in their neighborhood. We also provide technology training and assistance to help leverage the power of knowledge and transform it into meaningful action.

properties.Project Name: Strengthening Puget Sound Hands-On Stewardship and Intertidal Monitoring Project
properties.Short Project Summary: For the last 4 years, RE Sources has provided leadership and support to the volunteer-run Fidalgo Bay Aquatic Reserve Citizen Stewardship Committee, creating a strong intertidal monitoring program. The catalyst for taking on this work was simple: The Reserve lies adjacent to a refinery, and the Committee wanted to develop a comprehensive list of intertidal species that would help them monitor ongoing changes and fill data gaps that could prove useful in the event of an oil spill. This proposal aims to protect water quality in Puget Sound, and further guard against industrial impacts that could affect the entire Skagit Bay, by developing a more scientifically defensible protocol for monitoring temperature, pH, water quality and species diversity. A strong cadre of citizen stewards is poised to take this project to the next level of accountability.  RE Sources hopes to leverage their experience to create a newly reliable citizen science model for possible use throughout Puget Sound.

properties.Project Name: Burien Residential Rain Garden Pilot Project
properties.Short Project Summary: Inspired by the 12,000 Rain Gardens in Puget Sound campaign, the City of Burien investigated how many rain gardens they had themselves. However, when they could barely find any residential rain gardens in Burien, they knew something needed to change. Together with DIRT Corps and volunteers from the community, the City of Burien will install ten rain gardens on residential properties. The project will not only manage stormwater pollution and increase environmental awareness, but provide residential volunteers the knowledge necessary to continue building rain gardens in the community.

properties.Project Name: Tacoma Mall Neighborhood Depave Project
properties.Short Project Summary: The Pierce Conservation District will work with project partners and urban community groups to remove asphalt and concrete pavement from at least 5,000 square feet near the Tacoma Mall. The project partners will then install healthy soils within the project area and establish and maintain site-appropriate plants and trees.The target area for this project is the Tacoma Mall community. The community lies within two sensitive stormwater basins - Flett Creek and the Thea Foss Waterway. Flett Creek is an EPA target watershed which influences Chambers Creek, a salmon-bearing stream. The Thea Foss Waterway is a superfund site that has been remediated.The project will be conducted as a community driven process, and will include representation from the City of Tacoma and at least one neighborhood community council. About 100 volunteers will take part in depave and planting events designed to protect and remediate Central Puget Sound water quality.

properties.Project Name: Puget Sound Stormwater Language, Messaging and Outreach Material Development Project
properties.Short Project Summary: Futurewise proposes to work with partners to research, create and test stormwater terminology, imagery, messaging and materials that are �sticky� � that is, those that stick with our audience for a long time � so that residents in the Puget Sound Region will have significantly increased awareness of stormwater runoff impacts and will take action to implement best management practices and support implementation of stormwater management projects. The project will result in tested materials that we know are effective and can be used by agency and nonprofit staff throughout the region. This project is designed to reduce excess flows and decrease pollutant loading in the stormwater pathway resulting in improved ecosystem health in local waterways.In sum, we plan to develop high impact, effective messaging for stormwater topics that can be used consistently by all throughout the region. These will replace or enhance the largely untested messaging and outreach materials currently in use.

properties.Project Name: Edmonds Watershed Stewards
properties.Short Project Summary: The Edmonds Water Quality Stewards is a multi-faceted project to engage high school students & community members to improve water quality & awareness of pollution solutions. One aspect is a citizen science program led by Edmonds Woodway High School (EWHS) students & local community volunteers. This team collects ambient & stormwater water quality data from 16 locations in Edmonds streams throughout the year. This provides students hands-on experience collecting scientifically viable data, & provides needed baseline water quality data to inform decision makers. Furthermore, we will engage 4 EWHS biology classes in conducting bio-assessments of local streams utilizing habitat health & macroinvertebrate collection & identification. To reach the wider community, SSS will host a volunteer tree planting event. This work is crucial because the monitored streams flow into Edmonds Marsh, one of the last remaining saltwater marshes in Puget Sound, & data collected will support marsh restoration.

properties.Project Name: A Watershed Stewards Program for King County
properties.Short Project Summary: Seattle Tilth is building on nearly 20 years of experience in developing and implementing successful volunteer training and management programs to create a Watershed Stewards program that will provide up to 43 hours of training in watershed stewardship and community outreach to at least 40 King County volunteers from communities outside of Seattle. Once trained, these volunteers will add to the capacity of already existing efforts to engage community members to take action to improve water quality by providing 1,400 hours of community service, reaching over 2,500 people.

properties.Project Name: Protecting Washington's Waterways and Delicate Ecosystems from Dirty Fossil Fuels
properties.Short Project Summary: Stand respectfully requests a grant of $20,000 to pursue a multi-pronged strategy that builds upon our success in defeating Shell Oil�s Anacortes proposal by deepening the resistance to oil trains and fossil fuel-related infrastructure in Skagit County while we begin a planning process to make a just transition to a clean energy economy. Current oil trains to Tesoro�s Anacortes refinery � along with Tesoro�s proposal to expand its refinery � pose threats to the Puget Sound coastline, the Green-Duwamish River, and all of eastern Puget Sound�s tributaries north of Olympia. These watersheds are at risk of catastrophic pollution from accidents caused by trains carrying highly volatile, toxic crude oil in tank cars deemed unsafe by the National Transportation Safety Board. What�s more, if Tesoro�s refinery expansion is approved, there will be a perilous increase in tanker traffic and oil train traffic along the shores of the Puget Sound.

properties.Project Name: Normalizing Green Infrastructure
properties.Short Project Summary: Washington Environmental Council is working to transform stormwater management in Washington to utilize greener approaches. Rose Foundation support will be used to broadcast the success of on-the-ground green infrastructure projects funded by programs such as the state�s Stormwater Financial Assistance Program. We have a long way to go to restore Puget Sound, but the state is making progress and reducing stormwater pollution. To accelerate this progress, WEC will produce outreach and education materials to motivate action by the public, stormwater managers, and state decision makers.In effect, we are providing green infrastructure advocates with a bigger megaphone and these materials and our engagement plan will move Washington toward a new, sustainable stormwater paradigm. More local governments will embrace low-impact development (LID), more state grants will fund critical projects, and a larger base of people will be calling for actions to decrease pollution to Puget Sound.

properties.Project Name: Be a Toxic Free Zone Workshops
properties.Short Project Summary: The Port Townsend Marine Science Center (PTMSC) will motivate people to reduce toxics in their lives and their impact on Puget Sound water quality through fourteen 2-3 hour workshops customized to suit audiences with different needs. The workshops are adapted from a 6-week program that covers topics ranging from toxics in the home, garden, personal care products, and the food supply. We will lead people to take �the next step� in personal/collective action to reduce toxics that can enter the marine environment.

properties.Organization Name: Save Habitat and Diversity of Wetlands Org
properties.Project Name: SHADOW Lake Nature Preserve: Extend the Bog Tour
properties.Short Project Summary: Rapid urbanization in South King County and the lack of environmental education in the area pose a threat to the health of the Puget Sound. SHADOW Lake Nature Preserve's historic wetland system and education programming are uniquely equipped to address this threat at the community level. In order to effectively scale the impact of these resources SHADOW will need: - Support for staff time spent on community outreach  - To extend the boardwalk trail system - To strengthen web-based educational materials

properties.Project Name: Channeling Interest in Land-Based Whale Watching into Saving Puget Sound Drop-by-Drop
properties.Short Project Summary: Killer whales are among the most fascinating and charismatic species in Puget Sound, and while their popularity draws a lot of attention to their biology and delicate conservation status, the solutions for recovery are often mundane and overlooked. Whale Scout harnesses the admiration and energy of whale watchers and channels it towards native plants, streams, and our own homes, improving the water quality of Puget Sound for whales, salmon, and ourselves. We do this through educational experiences with volunteer naturalists on shorelines using "Save Orcas" brochures; direct salmon habitat restoration at "Helpin' Out" events; and our new PodMatch program, connecting up to 500,000 whale watchers each year with salmon habitat restoration events near their homes, scaling up our efforts significantly and providing cool, clean, water free of toxins for Puget Sound. Saving orcas is intrinsically linked to the water quality of Puget Sound.

properties.Project Name: Yahowt Native Women�s Circle
properties.Short Project Summary: Na�ah Illahee Fund�s Yahowt (Lushootseed Language �lift us up, together�) Circle of Native women will design and implement an ecological restoration project of the water filtration ponds located on the Daybreak Star Indian Cultural land, improving water quality of runoff from Discovery Park that empties into Puget Sound. The 30-year old ponds will be redesigned to include silt cleanup, invasive species removal, and planting of both floating and submerged native plants. The enhanced area will create a healthy and welcoming environment for both teaching and practicing traditional Indigenous lifeways through plant harvesting for medicine and cultural arts.

properties.Project Name: Depave the Duwamish
properties.Short Project Summary: Sustainable Seattle's Depave Program is entering the second year of its "Depave the Duwamish" project. Depave projects replace asphalt with green infrastructure that reduces storm water pollution, ameliorates heat islands and builds climate resilience, and improves community health. Seattle's lower Duwamish River Valley is comprised of more than 20,000 acres of highly industrialized hardscape that releases over 1.5 billion gallons/year of polluted storm water into the Duwamish River���a federal Superfund cleanup site. The Duwamish Valley has among the lowest green space acreage and tree canopy citywide, and is home to the low-income and highly diverse neighborhoods of South Park and Georgetown, which suffer from multiple environmental health disparities, including childhood asthma, heart disease, and a life expectancy seven years shorter than the city average. Year 1 of Sustainable Seattle's Depave the Duwamish project produced a basin-wide map identifying potential Depave sites on  industrial lands. Year 2 of the project will construct three demonstration Depave projects representing a variety of land ownerships and regulatory structures (e.g., private, city, school), and Year 3 will utilize lessons learned to develop a larger-scale Depave project through a public-private-community partnership that can serve as a model for a citywide Depave Program.

properties.Project Name: General Support: Hire a part-time staff person
properties.Short Project Summary: Grant funding will be used to hire a part-time staff person who will take over many of the oversight responsibilities of our ongoing projects, and work on securing new grants which will support our vision of improving the condition of the Green/Duwamish River watershed.  In the past, Green River Coalition (GRC) has operated without paid staff and has managed its projects solely with volunteer participation.   The combined effects of our recent successes in (1) starting up an intern program with the Natural Resources Department at Green River College, (2) being awarded a joint grant with Mid-Sound Fisheries Enhancement Group to conduct a streambank restoration project, (3) acquiring a support role in an EPA grant for restoration and education activities in the Covington, Washington vicinity and (4) being awarded a support role in an outreach program for streambank protection along the Newaukum  Creek tributary to the Green River have raised our workload to the level that our all-volunteer participation has reached its capacity to support it all.

properties.Project Name: Phthalates Research and Education for Source Control, Duwamish River and Commencement Bay
properties.Short Project Summary: Phthalates are a family of industrial chemicals which cause reproductive impacts in humans and wildlife and are a major concern in the stormwater pathway causing recontamination of Superfund sediment sites in Puget Sound. In this project, we will develop an inventory of exterior-use products used by businesses and agencies in the Duwamish River and Commencement Bay Superfund source areas which may contain phthalates by interviewing staff at these entities and conducting exterior visual site assessments. We will then prioritize and analyze phthalates in those products as well as in environmental samples from publicly accessible locations and conduct analysis of alternative products. Finally, we will conduct outreach to businesses and agencies about the results and available low/no phthalate alternative products. The project will be overseen by an Advisory Committee of agencies who conduct source control activities in the two cleanup areas. The goals are to reduce phthalates input into stormwater and improve source control, reduce impacts to humans who use the products, and provide information that can be used locally and nationally as we move away from toxic chemicals in products which cause impacts both during use and at end of the life of those products.

properties.Project Name: Matching grant for 60% design, Olympic Hills Pocket Park
properties.Short Project Summary: This is to fund the 60% design for restoration and planting of an undeveloped right-of-way in Lake City, Seattle, where a tributary to Thornton Creek flows through the Olympic Hills neighborhood. This former dump site has been cleaned up and beautified over the course of 3 years by 50+ volunteers. Residents worked with a professional design team to arrive at a design concept; we have completed the 30% design and construction drawings, and we seek to proceed through the 60% phase.

properties.Project Name: Squires Landing Park Restoration
properties.Short Project Summary: Squire's Landing Park is a 42-acre undeveloped parcel of land owned by the City of Kenmore located in the lower Swamp Creek drainage at its confluence with the Sammamish River near its outlet into Lake Washington. In 2012, the Washington Department of Ecology found that Swamp Creek violated state and federal water quality standards for dissolved oxygen, pH, and temperature which can be attributed to urbanization in the watershed increasing impervious surfaces and reducing forest cover. This project will increase native plant species diversity, remove invasive blackberry and reed canary grass, improve shade, water filtration, provide both cover and complex edge habitat for rearing juvenile and migrating adult Chinook and coho salmon. In particular, this grant will expand on the 2 acres of Squires Landing Park that have already been restored forming a 50 ft riparian buffer at the confluence of Swamp Creek and the Sammamish river by adding an additional acre on the south bank of Swamp Creek, 50 ft wide and extending 870 ft upstream from the previously planted area.

properties.Project Name: New Arrival Environmental Orientation
properties.Short Project Summary: Over the last three years ECOSS has hired and trained community coordinators from the Bhutanese and Burmese new arrival groups to recruit, engage and educate their respective communities on core environmental basics.  In the first year of the program, both new arrival groups identified water resources, access to local parks and fishing and shellfish gathering opportunities in our region as topics of most interest.  To date more than 400 youth and families have participated in organized trips to the Cedar River Watershed, community led and organized education dinners, youth performances related to water resources, and field trips to the Duwamish River, Hood Canal and Lake Washington for fishing and volunteer restoration events. With the support of the Rose Foundation, our vision is to integrate meaningful water quality and restoration activities for the purpose of enhancing ongoing environmental education programs and to expand the number of communities that we currently are able to serve.

properties.Project Name: WFC Strategic Initiative: Puget Sound Net Pens Pollution Reduction
properties.Short Project Summary: Piling on to threats to Puget Sound water quality, a foreign seafood company�s recent proposal to transform Puget Sound into an epicenter of net-pen farmed Atlantic salmon production will further degrade water quality and endanger the health of Puget Sound.  Last year Cooke Aquaculture, a Canadian company with major salmon farm operations in Chile, Spain, Scotland, Canada, and Maine, purchased Icicle Seafoods, which owned and operated eight Atlantic salmon net pen facilities currently in Puget Sound.
